ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: that Day will be a difficult day,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: It will be a day of distress,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: that will surely be a hard day,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: it will be a hard day
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: So that is a tough day.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Truly, that Day will be a Hard Day.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: That, at that time, shall be a difficult day,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: that day will be a harsh day,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Surely that day will be a day of anguish,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: that Day will be a hard and distressing Day.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: That shall be - that Day-a day hard.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: that will be a day of hardship,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: That will be- that Day - a Day of Distress,-
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Truly, that Day will be a Hard Day.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: that shall be a Harsh Day
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: That Day will be a difficult day.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: That Day will be a difficult day
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [74:9] that day, that is to say, the time of the sounding (yawma’idhin is a substitution for the preceding subject,   and is not declined because it is annexed to something that cannot be declined; the predicate of the subject [is the following]) will be a harsh day (idhā is operated by what is indicated by the statement: ishtadda’lamru, ‘[for when the trumpet is sounded] the situation will be terrible’),
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Surely that day) i.e. the Day of Judgement (will be a day of anguish) will be a severe day,
